If `f : â„ â†’ E` is an interval integrable function on `a..b` with `E` being a complete normed add commutative group, and `f` has a finite limit `c` almost surely at `b`, then `(d/dx) (x â†¦ âˆ« t in a..x, f t) = c` at `x = b`.

type:
âˆ€ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : â„ â†’ E} {c : E}
  {a b : â„},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b â†’
    StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhds b) MeasureTheory.volume â†’
      Filter.Tendsto f (nhds b âŠ“ MeasureTheory.volume.ae) (nhds c) â†’ deriv (fun u => âˆ« (x : â„) in a..u, f x) b = c
name: intervalIntegral.deriv_integral_of_tendsto_ae_right
docString: If `f : â„ â†’ E` is an interval integrable function on `a..b` with `E` being a complete normed add commutative group, and `f` has a finite limit `c` almost surely at `b`, then `(d/dx) (x â†¦ âˆ« t in a..x, f t) = c` at `x = b`.

This theorem is a version of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. It states that if `f : â„ â†’ E` is a function that is interval integrable on an interval `a..b` and the limit of `f` is a finite value `c` almost surely at `b`, then the derivative of the function `u â†¦ âˆ« x in a..u, f x` at point `b` equals `c`. Here, `E` is a normed add commutative group with a normed space structure over the real numbers â„ and is also a complete space. The limit of `f` at `b` is taken with respect to the neighborhood filter at `b` intersected with the almost everywhere filter of the Lebesgue measure.

  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b â†’
    StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhds b) MeasureTheory.volume â†’
      Filter.Tendsto f (nhds b âŠ“ MeasureTheory.volume.ae) (nhds c) â†’ deriv (fun u => âˆ« (x : â„) in a..u, f x) b = c

Here, `E` is a normed add commutative group with a normed space structure over the real numbers â„ and is also a complete space. The limit inferior of the integral of an almost-everywhere measurable sequence of extended nonnegative real-valued functions with respect to a measure is less than or equal to the integral of their limit inferior. In mathematical notation, this is written as:

\[ \int_{\alpha} \liminf_{n \to \infty} f_n(a) \,d\mu(a) \leq \liminf_{n \to \infty} \int_{\alpha} f_n(a) \,d\mu(a) \]

type:
âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {m : MeasurableSpace Î±} {Î¼ : MeasureTheory.Measure Î±} {f : â„• â†’ Î± â†’ ENNReal},
  (âˆ€ (n : â„•), AEMeasurable (f n) Î¼) â†’
    âˆ«â» (a : Î±), Filter.liminf (fun n => f n a) Filter.atTop âˆ‚Î¼ â‰¤
      Filter.liminf (fun n => âˆ«â» (a : Î±), f n a âˆ‚Î¼) Filter.atTop
name: MeasureTheory.lintegral_liminf_le'
docString:
The limit inferior of the integral of an almost-everywhere measurable sequence of extended nonnegative real-valued functions with respect to a measure is less than or equal to the integral of their limit inferior. In mathematical notation, this is written as:

\[ \int_{\alpha} \liminf_{n \to \infty} f_n(a) \,d\mu(a) \leq \liminf_{n \to \infty} \int_{\alpha} f_n(a) \,d\mu(a) \]

This theorem states that if the expression `(f y - f x) / (y - x)` tends to a certain limit as `y` approaches `x` (possibly only from one side or along certain lines), then the same limiting behavior holds for the expression `(f (y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) - d) / (y - x)`. This is essentially saying that adding a small perturbation `(c * (y - x) ^ 2)` to the argument of `f` in the numerator doesn't change the limiting behavior. This theorem is particularly useful in the study of almost everywhere differentiability of monotone functions, where such perturbations often arise.

type:
âˆ€ {f : â„ â†’ â„} {x a c d : â„} {l : Filter â„},
  l â‰¤ nhdsWithin x {x}á¶œ â†’
    Filter.Tendsto (fun y => (f y - d) / (y - x)) l (nhds a) â†’
      Filter.Tendsto (fun y => y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) l l â†’
        Filter.Tendsto (fun y => (f (y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) - d) / (y - x)) l (nhds a)
name: tendsto_apply_add_mul_sq_div_sub
docString: This theorem states that if the expression `(f y - f x) / (y - x)` tends to a certain limit as `y` approaches `x` (possibly only from one side or along certain lines), then the same limiting behavior holds for the expression `(f (y + c * (y - x) ^ 2) - d) / (y - x)`. This is essentially saying that adding a small perturbation `(c * (y - x) ^ 2)` to the argument of `f` in the numerator doesn't change the limiting behavior. This theorem is particularly useful in the study of almost everywhere differentiability of monotone functions, where such perturbations often arise.

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : â„ â†’ E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely at `a`, then the derivative of `u â†¦ âˆ« x in u..b, f x` at `a` equals `-c`.

type:

Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : â„ â†’ E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `b` from the right or from the left, then the right
(resp., left) derivative of `u â†¦ âˆ« x in a..u, f x` at `b` equals `c`.

type:
âˆ€ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : â„ â†’ E} {c : E}
  {a b : â„},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b â†’
    âˆ€ {s t : Set â„} [inst_3 : intervalIntegral.FTCFilter b (nhdsWithin b s) (nhdsWithin b t)],
      StronglyMeasurableAtFilter f (nhdsWithin b t) â†’
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin b t âŠ“ MeasureTheory.Measure.ae MeasureTheory.volume) (nhds c) â†’
          autoParam (UniqueDiffWithinAt â„ s b) _autoâœ â†’ derivWithin (fun u => âˆ« (x : â„) in a..u, f x) s b = c
name: intervalIntegral.derivWithin_integral_of_tendsto_ae_right
docString:
Fundamental theorem of calculus: if `f : â„ â†’ E` is integrable on `a..b` and `f x` has a finite
limit `c` almost surely as `x` tends to `b` from the right or from the left, then the right
(resp., left) derivative of `u â†¦ âˆ« x in a..u, f x` at `b` equals `c`.

Fundamental theorem of calculus-2: If `f : â„ â†’ E` is continuous on `[a, b]` (where `a â‰¤ b`) and
has a derivative at `f' x` for all `x` in `(a, b)`, and `f'` is integrable on `[a, b]`, then
`âˆ« y in a..b, f' y` equals `f b - f a`.

type:
âˆ€ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f f' : â„ â†’ E}
  {a b : â„},
  a â‰¤ b â†’
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) â†’
      (âˆ€ x âˆˆ Set.Ioo a b, HasDerivAt f (f' x) x) â†’
        IntervalIntegrable f' MeasureTheory.volume a b â†’ âˆ« (y : â„) in a..b, f' y = f b - f a
name: intervalIntegral.integral_eq_sub_of_hasDerivAt_of_le
docString:
Fundamental theorem of calculus-2: If `f : â„ â†’ E` is continuous on `[a, b]` (where `a â‰¤ b`) and
has a derivative at `f' x` for all `x` in `(a, b)`, and `f'` is integrable on `[a, b]`, then
`âˆ« y in a..b, f' y` equals `f b - f a`.
